raw_text:
BBC to pour £9m into new comedy
 
 The BBC is to invest £9m in developing new comedy and entertainment programmes outside London.
 
 The changes come as part of a shake-up of several departments to create shows that appeal to a wider range of people. Changes are also being made to teams in the factual and daytime departments outside London. Director of television Jana Bennett said the changes were about "getting the best ideas on screen as efficiently and effectively as we can". "The new structure in each genre is designed to ensure that happens," she said.
 
 A number of new roles are being created in each department, including a head of comedy commissioning based in Glasgow. The new person will be in charge of the £9m budget and their role will be to develop shows outside the capital, both within the BBC and with independent production companies. Jane Lush, controller of entertainment commissioning, said, "Entertainment and comedy are incredibly important to our audiences; I'm confident these changes will help us get the very best programmes on screen." Similar positions will also be created in the other departments, with the new commissioning editor for documentaries based in Bristol and the daytime commissioning editor in Birmingham. Ms Bennett said the new roles would benefit those making programmes within the BBC as well as those making shows for the channel independently. "A strong independent sector and a flourishing in-house production base are not mutually exclusive and will stimulate the competition that will deliver the best ideas to the audience," she said.

The changes aim to appeal to a wider range of audiences through new programming strategies and efficient production processes.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The BBC is investing £9 million in developing new comedy and entertainment programs outside London.
This change comes as part of a restructuring plan involving several departments.
New roles are being created for staff in comedy commissioning (Glasgow), documentaries commissioning (Bristol), and daytime commissioning (Birmingham).

tinyllama:1.1b: The BBC has announced changes to several departments, including investing £9m into developing new comedy and entertainment programs outside London as part of a wider shake-up of its operations.

The changes are aimed at creating shows that appeal to a wider range of people by ensuring the most effective and efficient use of resources in the department for factual and daytime programming, which is being reorganized into new roles based in Glasgow and Bristol respectively.
Ms Jan Luš, controller of entertainment commissioning, said the changes will help ensure the best ideas are brought to the audience.

The shake-up includes the creation of new positions with a head of comedy commissioning at Glasgow, and a daytime commissioning editor for Birminham and Bristol, as well as several other changes in departments.
The move is part of an effort to create shows that appeal to a wider range of people and promote the competition between programs within the BBC as well as those made by independent producers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The BBC is set to invest £9m in developing new comedy and entertainment programmes outside London as part of a shake-up aimed at reaching a wider range of people.
The changes come as part of a reorganization plan that also sees directors of television Jana Bennett and Jane Lush take on new roles within the BBC's factual and daytime departments outside London.

Both Jana Bennett and Jane Lush have emphasized the importance of bringing creative ideas to life in different parts of the country, with a particular focus on Glasgow and Glasgow-based production companies.
They believe these changes will help the BBC deliver the best shows for its audiences while also encouraging collaboration and experimentation across various genres.

The revised structure also includes new roles for heads of comedy commissioning based in Glasgow, with Jane Lush stating, "Entertainment and comedy are incredibly important to our audiences; I'm confident these changes will help us get the very best programmes on screen."
Ms Bennett emphasized that the new roles would benefit both those making programmes within the BBC as well as those making shows for the channel independently.
The reorganization plan is meant to boost competition among the industry and stimulate innovation, while also providing better quality entertainment for viewers.
